Liverpool Street revamp gets green light

What happened: The City of London has approved Network Rail’s £1.2bn redevelopment (artist impression) of London Liverpool Street, the UK’s busiest station. The plan includes a mixed-use 97m tower built above the concourse, plus major station upgrades. A planning application was first filed in 2023, then revised after thousands of objections, with new plans unveiled in November and further tweaks in April.

Why it matters: Liverpool Street is a Grade II-listed heritage site, so the approval sets a precedent for how aggressively London will “build up” over historic transport hubs. Supporters argue it is essential capacity planning, Network Rail says concourse capacity will rise 76%, with better passenger flow, more lifts and escalators, and step-free access to all platforms and the Underground. Critics, including the Victorian Society, call it a disfiguring office-led scheme that demolishes listed buildings and harms a conservation area.

Criticism: Campaigners will now look to the mayor of London and potentially the secretary of state for further intervention. Passenger demand is forecast to hit 158 million annually, so delivery timelines and disruption management will matter.

Mega office deals roar back

What happened: London’s office market rebounded in 2025, with big lettings and investment deals returning as “return to office” momentum strengthened, and interest rates eased.

Highlight deals:

  • CoStar counted 14 new lettings above 100,000 sq ft, double 2024, and net absorption of just under 4 million sq ft, the best occupancy gain since 2018.
  • On the investment side, there were 19 office transactions over £100m, up 73% year on year, plus eight £200m-plus deals, up from one in 2024.
  • Landmark sales included Hayfin buying 70 St Mary Axe for £330m (5.5% yield) and Royal London paying £250m for 1 Newman Street (4.5% yield).

Why it matters: A tighter construction pipeline and improving lending conditions are pushing prime rents higher, with £200/sq ft increasingly normal in the West End and £150/sq ft in the City.

What to watch: More action in older towers via refurbishments, not new builds, as high costs and tougher planning slow fresh supply.

Long story short

 

Politics & Crown
• Downing Street refused to say whether Labour peer Matthew Doyle could lose his peerage after allegations he failed to disclose campaigning for someone charged with sex offences. No 10 said it won’t “get ahead” of Labour’s internal investigation and claimed there’s no precedent for withdrawing a peerage after it’s announced. Ministers say they plan legislation to allow peerages to be removed for misconduct, initially aimed at Peter Mandelson.
• King Charles III is distancing himself more from his brother Andrew as new Epstein-related documents emerge. Since October, Charles has stripped Andrew of the “prince” title, removed him from Royal Lodge, and publicly backed Epstein’s victims. After Thames Valley Police said it was assessing fresh allegations, Buckingham Palace made the rare move of saying it would cooperate if approached, aiming to contain the fallout to Andrew and protect the monarchy.

Business
• Activist American hedge fud Elliott Management has built a “significant” stake in London Stock Exchange Group and is pressuring for performance improvements, potentially including a new share buyback. LSEG shares jumped up to 6% on the news, despite being down over 35% in the past year amid worries about fewer listings and AI disrupting its data business. LSEG says it’s in active dialogue with investors.
• UK fintech funding fell 21% last year to about US$11bn, the lowest since 2020, with 418 deals versus 527 in 2024, per KPMG (using PitchBook data). Revolut’s ~US$4bn raise at a US$75bn valuation made up a big share. The UK still out-raised several regions combined, but lagged the US. Globally, fintech funding rose to US$116bn, with M&A jumping.
 

Art & culture
•
UCL celebrates turning 200. Founded in 1826 as “The London University” and renamed in 1836, it pushed against the Oxbridge model early, opening doors across class and creed. In 1878 it admitted women across most faculties, then helped invent modern student life with an officially recognised union. Its hospital partnership shaped European anaesthesia, endured wartime damage, and treated 7/7 victims.
• Noel Clarke has been arrested by the Metropolitan Police on suspicion of attempted rape, exposure, and sexual assault by touching, linked to an alleged 2007 incident in London involving a woman in her 20s. Police also questioned him about a separate voyeurism allegation from 2013. He has been bailed while the investigation continues.

Did you know?
 

There are fake “townhouses” that are actually just a wall: 23-24 Leinster Gardens hide gaps in the Underground line.
